Case 1:20-cr-00330-PAE Document 565 Filed 12/19/21 Page 43 of 83

1 Instruction No. 33: Counts One, Three, and Five: Conspiracy to Violate Federal Law - First Element
2
3 Starting with the first element, what is a conspiracy? A conspiracy is an agreement or an
4 understanding, between two or more persons, to accomplish by joint action a criminal or
5 unlawful purpose.
6
7 The essence of the crime of conspiracy is the unlawful agreement between two or more
8 people to violate the law. As I mentioned earlier, the ultimate success of the conspiracy, meaning
9 the actual commission of the crime that is the object of the conspiracy, is not an element of the
10 crime of conspiracy.
11 In order to show that a conspiracy existed, the evidence must show that two or more
12 people, in some way or manner, through any contrivance, explicitly or implicitly (that is, spoken
13 or unspoken), came to a mutual understanding to violate the law and to accomplish an unlawful
14 plan. Express language or specific words are not required to indicate assent or attachment to a
15 conspiracy. If you find beyond a reasonable doubt that two or more persons came to an
16 understanding, express or implied, to violate the law and to accomplish an unlawful plan, then
17 the Government will have sustained its burden of proof as to this element.
18 To show that a conspiracy existed, the Government is not required to show that two or
19 more people sat around a table and entered into a solemn pact, orally or in writing, stating that
20 they had formed a conspiracy to violate the law and spelling out all of the details. Common sense
21 tells you that when people, in fact, agree to enter into a criminal conspiracy, much is left to the
22 unexpressed understanding. It is rare that a conspiracy can be proven by direct evidence of an
23 explicit agreement. Conspirators do not usually reduce their agreements to writing or
24 acknowledge them before a notary public, nor do they publicly broadcast their plans.

42
DOJ-OGR-00008749

text_blocks.content: 1 Instruction No. 33: Counts One, Three, and Five: Conspiracy to Violate Federal Law - First Element

Starting with the first element, what is a conspiracy? A conspiracy is an agreement or an understanding, between two or more persons, to accomplish by joint action a criminal or unlawful purpose. The essence of the crime of conspiracy is the unlawful agreement between two or more people to violate the law. As I mentioned earlier, the ultimate success of the conspiracy, meaning the actual commission of the crime that is the object of the conspiracy, is not an element of the crime of conspiracy. In order to show that a conspiracy existed, the evidence must show that two or more people, in some way or manner, through any contrivance, explicitly or implicitly (that is, spoken or unspoken), came to a mutual understanding to violate the law and to accomplish an unlawful plan. Express language or specific words are not required to indicate assent or attachment to a conspiracy. If you find beyond a reasonable doubt that two or more persons came to an understanding, express or implied, to violate the law and to accomplish an unlawful plan, then the Government will have sustained its burden of proof as to this element. To show that a conspiracy existed, the Government is not required to show that two or more people sat around a table and entered into a solemn pact, orally or in writing, stating that they had formed a conspiracy to violate the law and spelling out all of the details. Common sense tells you that when people, in fact, agree to enter into a criminal conspiracy, much is left to the unexpressed understanding. It is rare that a conspiracy can be proven by direct evidence of an explicit agreement. Conspirators do not usually reduce their agreements to writing or acknowledge them before a notary public, nor do they publicly broadcast their plans.

additional_notes: The document appears to be a court instruction related to a conspiracy case. The text is clear and legible, with no visible redactions or damage.
